text: on tuesday president bush and treasury
secretary henry paulson announced that
the government would inject up to 250
billion dollars into the nation's
banking system this is part of the 700
billion dollar program the congress just
recently approved to help the financial
system
at first nine large financial
institutions will get money banks like
citigroup wells fargo goldman sachs
morgan stanley and so forth eventually
the money will also be distributed to
smaller banks the way to think about it
is that a bank would use the 250 billion
dollars as capital and they could borrow
more money against that from the private
market so
that 250 billion dollars could
essentially turn into two and a half
trillion dollars of actual lending
ability for for the banks because they
usually are able to borrow ten times as
much as they have capital this afternoon
credit markets uh looked like they were
improving a little bit but investors and
analysts said that you know the the
improvement so far has been very modest
the hope is that as this money becomes
available to the banks and the banks
start using it and putting it to work
that uh interest rates would come down
for for some of the kinds of loans that
we've become used to having i mean the
30-year fixed rate mortgage loan in
recent weeks has been around six percent
or more um you know conceivably if this
plan works as it's supposed to those
rates could come down you know those
rates have been as low as five and a
half or five percent um in recent years
analysts said that the 250 billion
dollar injection should certainly help
prevent a financial meltdown of the
kinds we saw after lehman brothers
declared bankruptcy in september but
they also note that it's unlikely to
avert economic recession it's unlikely
to prevent further job losses and will
certainly have more corporate failures
in the next few months
